sections.name: I - Answer in Writing (Short)
sections.description: Attempt all questions. Each question carries 2 marks.

questions.question: Why did Dobereiner's triads fail to include all known elements?
Are elements in Newlands' octaves *identical* or just *similar* to the first in the series?
Did Mendeleev see the gaps in his table as errors or as predictions?
How did Moseley's X-ray work change the basis of the periodic table?
Is the *total* number of electrons or the *outer shell* most important in the modern periodic law?

sections.name: II - Answer in Writing (Long)
sections.description: Attempt all questions. Each question carries 4 marks.

questions.question: Before Mendeleev, describe the thought process for creating a better element classification system.
How did Moseley resolve Mendeleev's 'anomalous pairs' and provide a more fundamental ordering?
Explain periods and groups using electron configurations: (a) period start/end? (b) group similarity?
Relate *two* of these: atomic radius, ionization energy, electronegativity. How does one affect the other?
Explain s, p, d, and f blocks, linking them to electron subshells, and give an example of each.

sections.name: III - Multiple Choice Questions
sections.description: Attempt all questions. Each question carries 1 mark.

questions.question: Robert Boyle defined an element as a substance that cannot be further broken down by what means?
choices: Heating it to extremely high temperatures.
Only by using very strong acids.

questions.question: Döbereiner's law of triads grouped elements based on what?
According to Newlands' law of octaves, elements were arranged in ascending order of what?
Mendeleev divided his periodic table into vertical columns called what?
The modern periodic law states that the properties of elements are a periodic function of their what?

sections.name: IV - Fill in the Blanks
sections.description: Complete all sentences. Each blank carries 1 mark.

questions.question: Robert Boyle defined an element as any substance that cannot be ________ into a further simple substance by a physical or chemical change.
Döbereiner stated that the atomic weight of the ________ element is the average of the atomic weights of the first and third elements in a triad.
Newlands' law of octaves states that when elements are arranged in ascending order of their atomic weights, their ________ repeat at regular intervals.
Mendeleev arranged elements in increasing order of their ________ weights.
Moseley realized that the ________ number is a more fundamental characteristic of an element than its atomic weight.
